question.content:
$\sec(\theta) = \dfrac{13}{5}$ for an acute angle $\theta$.

**Evaluate the expression without the use of a calculator.**

$\tan(\theta) + \cot(\theta)=$ [[â˜ƒ numeric-input 1]]

hints.content:
Let's imagine a right triangle with an acute angle of $\theta$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/ec9fcaeb6b7adafb27842298938b7c632d941768)

$\sec(\theta)$ gives the ratio of the $\purpleC{\text{hypotenuse}}$ and the side $\maroonD{\text{adjacent}}$ to $\theta$. We are given that this ratio is $\dfrac{\purpleC{13}}{\maroonD{5}}$. Let's say the sides are $\maroonD{5}$ units and $\purpleC{13}$ units long, even though they can really be any multiple of that.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/c7bdf6862a0c505e383a88fc9dd52b39e7977e98)

We can now use the Pythagorean theorem to find the third side and use that to evaluate $\tan(\theta) + \cot(\theta)$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/65670851290d501faae576d455b55bf04b6aa6fa)

According to the Pythagorean theorem:

$\begin{align}
x^2 + 5^2 &= 13^2 \\\\
x^2 +25 &= 169 \\\\
x^2 &= 144 \\\\
x &= 12
\end{align}$

So, the $\blueD{\text{opposite}}$   side is $12$ units long.

Now we can plug the values of $\tan(\theta)$ and $\cot(\theta)$ in the given expression:

$\tan(\theta) + \cot(\theta)= \dfrac{12}{5} + \dfrac{5}{12}  = \dfrac{169}{60}$
